reviewText: My husband started watching sons and kept telling me to watch with him. After a few days of nagging I was "ok"! This show is amazing. The acting and drama between each character is so genuine. I love the cameos of actors that come in as random characters. I thought it was going to be raunchy and lame. It was crazy action packed. Each character is so well acted they don't do things out of character just to complete a story line. At the end of the episode it all makes sense. There is plenty of drama for me and plenty of action and motorcycles for my husband. We actually talk about it when the shows not on because we are so connected to the characters. Just watch and you will see you will be hooked you won't be able to help yourself. You will end up like me searching the internet for season 5....I tell you its KILLING me.

reviewText: This season has had its ups and downs.  I can't imagine why they would carry it into one more year, but they are, and I'm pretty sure that I won't be watching until it comes out on Netflix streaming, if at all.That said, this review is starred only for this episode.  It is obvious that they want to build to a big end.  This episode does everything but stand on its head to set up the final episode.  I believe they knew they didn't have enough plot built previous to this episode to have a "spectacular" finale, and they probably have been scrambling to segue into the next season.What came out of this episode was a garbled, predictable story-line...just as predictable as knowing Clay has a further role at the end of the last episode.  Of course, mayhem will break loose in the finale.  Just like an episode of Columbo or Murder, She wrote, the formula will take us where the writers and producers want us, no matter how transparent it may be.There have been some fairly decent episodes this year, and there are actors from Deadwood, a truly great series here, as well as Danny Trejo, "Tortuga" from Breaking Bad and other choice roles, down-playing his skills, but stil interesting.  It's been a better season than last year overall, but this episode is just a soap opera stinker.  Way, way too formulaic.

reviewText: "Sons Of Anarchy: Season Four"NOTE: Mild spoilers below. Don't freak out.On its own, this season of SOA would probably get a 4-star rating: the first few episodes were hard to get into and the entire subplot about Juice being afraid of being "outed" as an African-American simply didn't ring true: the Sons spent their first two seasons combating the local white supremacist gang, and had expressed a dislike of their ideology. Now, suddenly, they're all racist themselves and Juice is so flipped out about it that he's willing to rat them out to the Feds? Sorry -- I don't buy it. It was way too forced and didn't serve that great a dramatic purpose. Meanwhile, Jax is still wringing his hands about what to do with his life and is still spinning around in the same should-I-stay-or-should-I-go? circles he's been running in for the entire show.  I know this is meant to be a Hamlet parallel, but it's starting to wear thin.  Also, the new Top Cop character was a little too "quirky" for my tastes. Still, by the time the second half of the season rolled around, we were transfixed, and wanted to see what was going to happen next. The last couple of episodes were sharp enough to make us eager to see what happens next.The reason I'm giving the show a 1-star rating, though, is as a protest vote against Amazon's new monopolistic sales policies, in which they are colluding with HBO, Fox and other companies to forbid Amazon customers from reselling their DVDs on Amazon: you can buy "Sons Of Anarchy" on Amazon, but if you try to sell it used, suddenly it's a "restricted item" and they won't let you. What's worse is they will allow *some* Amazon-affiliated sellers to provide it used, but not regular folks like you and me. The idea is, apparently, to crack down on bootlegs as well as artificially boost the used prices and, I would imagine, to push more customers towards Amazon's vastly inferior download and streaming video services, so that the video companies don't "lose" more money through re-sales. Well, since I bought this show brand new, directly from Amazon, I don't think it's a bootleg, and I think that I should be able to resell it there as well, as I've always been able to before. Now, if Amazon wanted to stop ALL used sales on their site altogether, that would be one thing, but playing favorites with "pre-approved" sellers seems pretty unfair and smells a bit like monopoly practices to me. Just one more reason to migrate away from Amazon's sphere of influence, I guess. I really don't like the high-handed way Amazon is treating its customers these days. (Axton)
summary: Not happy with Amazon's monopoly practices

reviewText: Every season of soa has been unpredictable, funny, dramatic, surprising and brutal. Season 4 was no different. So much betrayal and once again you just can't predict what will happen next. The most members died this season including an original "Piney" which sucked but man did it set up for what will be a very bloody season 5. A lot of people complained about the finale not being crazy enough etc but come on, the finales won't always be like that. No one could of predicted that the cartel were cia agents the whole time which changed the whole future for Jax and Tara. Jax and Tara being at the head of the table at the end gave me chills especially when it flashed back to John and Gemma. This show to me is the greatest ever and not just in the story line but the music just sets the tone too from well known music to awesome unknown. Season 4 is my 2nd favorite season behind season 3 and season 5 is set up to be a huge war. It will be amazing just like every season has been. SOA4LIFE!

reviewText: I had never really seen much of this series in the past, but after watching this I have already looked into the first three seasons to catch up on what I missed. This is an action packed show and in this season you are kept on the edge of your seat in every episode (or at least I was). I was impressed with the overall acting within the show itself and the relationships between the characters were very solid. As I said before there is plenty of action in the series, but you also will find drama and even if you are not into the motorcycle scene, you will still find a lot to enjoy about the series. There are definitely references to biking culture that you have to catch onto, but you can catch on quite quickly and once you do it is smooth sailing!
summary: A Great Series for Bikers and Non-Bikers Alike

reviewText: Motorcycle gangs.  Shoot outs.  Tough guys.  Rock 'n roll.  This is a MAN'S show, correct?  No soapy stuff here.  Not correct.  This is through and through a SOAP OPERA, disguised with the leather jackets and tough guys.  Don't get me wrong - this is an excellent show.  It is definitely captivating, the acting is great, and it is NON-STOP drama and action.  As far as one of the best shows EVER?  I think some people are getting ahead of themselves.The thing that really separates the epitome of excellent television (The Wire, The Sopranos, Breaking Bad) from very good television (Sons of Anarchy, for example), is the fact that in the first types of shows, people don't really change.  This mimics real life, where people generally remain relatively the same over long periods of time once they reach a certain age.  Of course people can do complete 180s in their lives and change, but at the core....people generally remain the same.  EXCELLENT television is generally a little slow moving in character development, since in real life people don't change from day to day.  These shows don't rely on cheap thrills and love triangles and constant jaw-dropping character changes and motives.  They have to rely on...wait for this....great writing.Enter Sons of Anarchy.  It is one of the biggest rollercoaster emotional ride experience on television, with people and their motives CONSTANTLY changing and evolving from episode to episode.  People get kidnapped, everyone is a liar and a backstabber, and one minute something is a crucial element to the plot, and the next it's dropped/forgiven/forgotten.  The writers are masters at creating drama and non-stop action, but as far as realistic portrayals of human beings (something that the show is trying to achieve - make us empathize with these characters), this gets a 4/10.  They are the show that relies on cheap thrills and twists to make a show.  Does it make it bad?  Not necessarily.  Not every show is made to be in the ranks of shows like The Sopranos.  Kurt Sutter has commented that all of the excess, ridiculous, over-the-top drama is purposeful and for good television.  This is quite probable, but is it an excuse or the truth?  With the way some of the characters act (Gemma in particular), I believe that the show is trying to make me feel like this show is more than just constant drama and twists, but something more deep and meaningful.  And I'm not feeling it.The acting is really great, there is no denying that.  I'm still not convinced that I buy Ron Perlman (Clay) as tough biker, but I've come to deal with it.  This is a very Clay-focused season.  Katey Sagal as Gemma is wonderful as always, and is absolutely superb with the material she is given.  My only problem with her character is that sometimes the writers push the "matriarch" card a little too hard.  Ever see the end of Mystic River, where the wife gives Sean Penn that "king" speech?  Every time Gemma talks it sort of reminds me of that, and it's a little annoying after 4 seasons.  Also, Maggie Siff as Tara Knowles continues to bore the hell out of me, and it's been obvious since season 1 that they are setting her up to become the new "matriarch" of the club.  Predictable/cliche, much?I also still can't forgive the sudden drop of Wendy (Drea de Mateo) in season 2.  In season 1 she is living with Jax and there is a major storyline between Gemma/Tara/Wendy, and in the next season Wendy completely dropped off the face of the earth along with the storyline, and then she returns this season.....?  Disjointed storylines like this are never signs of excellent television.  Her character was inconvenient for the growth of Tara/Jax, so they just dropped her.  Lazy writing.Charlie Hunnam is an amazing actor (can you believe he is a British stage actor?) and totally convincing for his role.  Everyone else is very good - I love Kim Coates, Mark Boone Junior, Theo Rossi, Tommy Flanagan, and probably my favorite - Dayton Callie as Wayne Unser.  He was terrific in Deadwood, and equally great in this show.  The show still has a total obsession with using Deadwood characters - over 13 to date, but that's a great thing and they make a great addition to the show.  This season we're joined by Ray McKinnon, another Deadwood actor (the Reverend!) as Assistant U.S. Attorney, Lincoln Potter, and as usual, this guy is just amazingly weird and a terrific addition to the cast.SoA is not lacking in drama or great acting, but I think a more slow-paced show (somewhat like the first season) would do it justice and make it a little less silly and a little more gritty.  I definitely recommend this show to anyone though that is interested in a high-action, intense, dramatic show with lots of twists, turns, extremely sappy moments and great acting performances.  Even with the all of the criticism I gave it, it's still easily in the top 10 best dramas currently on television, hence the high rating.  I'm definitely not going to stop watching.

reviewText: I've been a fan since season 1.  The end of Season three reveals the suggested fate of Jax's father in letters which Tara reads(which plays a major role in season 4).I was estatic to get the fourth installment of Sons of Anarchy.  From start to finish, not one bad episode!With new law enforcement in Charming headed by LT. Roosevelt, U.S. Attorney Lincoln Potter teaming up with LT. Roosevelt, Dealing with gun running & drug trafficing with Romeo, Juicy facing pressure from the law about his past, Russian mob, Irish cartel, & topping it off with Gemma and Clays fears of the Piney & Tara's knowledge of the letters proves to be some of the best writing of the season yet.These events really put on the pressure developing friction within the club.  These events put such a strain on the club, it shows how members, such as Clay, will do what it takes to stay ahead.  Even in the end there are those who can't escape what it buried in the past, & there are those that can only delay the inevitable.  There are those whose fates are just around the corner.There is so much ground this season covers, I probably didn't do this review justice.My only complaint is the DVD itself.  I noticed that the subtitles tend to freeze a couple of times on a couple of episodes.  It doesn't bother me, but it could be a problem for the hearing impaired.  I actually give this 4.5 out of 5 stars becuase of this.  Other than that, a great addition to the DVD collection.
summary: Does it go down hill from here, or do you rise above it all?

reviewText: The Sons of Anarchy is a very good TV series that my wife and I enjoy. It is full of action and the script and acting are very good. Season 4 starts with the Sons getting out of jail after 14 months and heading home. A new sheriff in town stops them and tells them they can't wear their colors or they will be in violation of their parole. Things have changed a lot in the last 14 months, new sheriff, a new suburban development is going full bore into construction and a new US Attorney is in Charming under cover to get rid of SAMCRO by building a RICO case.The Sons set a trap and kill the Russian mob members at a wedding and then set up a meeting with a drug cartel to sell them heavy weapons. In a joint deal Clay agrees to smuggle drugs for the cartel and club is divided over being drug mules which is something they never wanted to get involved in. The money is good but the risks are high and the penalties and dangers are something some gang members do not want to deal with.Season 4 in my opinion is one of the best of the series and Clay's out of control actions put everyone at risk. Clay will do everything to remain at the top of SAMCRO including murder and lying, things that he is used to doing. This season has a lot of action and is gory as murders and violence increase as the plot unwinds. Clay's actions are over the top and Jax decides that he must do something to rein him under control.If you like Sons of Anarchy you will love this DVD set of Season 4. You will not be able to stop watching the episodes until you are done. This series just seems to get better as time goes along and I can't wait for Season 5.
summary: Suspense and action filled, this series just continues to get better!

reviewText: OK - I'll admit to being hooked. This is a great show. What keeps it from being perfect IMHO is Dr. Tara. She looks too young to have the career that she does. She'd be more like a resident than a top surgeon. What keeps bugging me is how a doctor, presumably able to at least buy groceries and pay the rent, would want ANYTHING to do with a lifestyle that mainly involves committing multiple felonies, up to and including murder, on a fairly routine basis. And as the 3rd season showed, she'll do more than just watch. Her peers are now porn stars and MC old ladies, not fellow doctors. Also note the "love of the club" seems to be a tool used by the leader(s) to control or manipulate the rank and file. I guess this is no different from any real life crime gang, which is what this club is.Also maybe someone can explain why the local criminals need huge amounts of military-grade weapons???
summary: It is great and addicting but not 100% perfect
Title: N/A

reviewText: How did garbage like this ever get on TV in the first place?  And once it did, how is possible that millions of people are entertained by it?I mean, "The Sons of Anarchy" is nothing more than a glorification of a despicably violent, grimy American sub-culture that spits in the face of Mom, The Flag, and Apple Pie.But I love it!  And am now counting the days (months... almost a year) until I get my hands on the DVD of Season Five.  Yeah, I know I can watch Season Five unfold right now, but I don't watch commercial TV... not even if I can record it and fast-forward through the ads.But back to the "Sons."  This is some great stuff, I'd say.  Character development, script writing. and plot twists that are off the charts.  Brilliant work!  On the level of "The Sopranos," and maybe even beyond it.So... all praise to the creators of this show!  It's a real piece of work.  Masterful in every way.

reviewText: What to say about SOA...Well, I'm not normally into these types of shows. I don't like crooked cops and I like criminals even less, but holy smokes! I watched the first episode and I had to watch the next and then the next and so on and so forth. Now, I would not have purchased this season because I don't know how many times I will watch it over and over again, but I could not leave SOA and not see where the story was going. The season wasn't free...yet. So I purchased it. I'm not sorry I did, but then a week later Prime put it out for free. Oh well. I'll be purchasing Season 5 when it comes out...Very few shows get you rooting for the bad guys or leave you at the end of the show wondering what's going to happen next. That was the problem. I would watch one episode and the way it ended would force me to watch the next one. That's the way it went until I finished season 4.
summary: Never thought I'd be a SOA follower

reviewText: The fourth season of "Sons of Anarchy" unfolds the tensions to a slower,more  deliberate rate than in past seasons. Then after a boiling point is reached, the struggles take off at rather exciting rates. A secret often alluded to in previous seasons peels away more and more information with serious consequences.  The resulting suspense produces very dramatic scenes. Relationships between characters shift swiftly and are well portrayed.Unlike the third season, where the major conflicts were resolved by the actions of the characters, outside factors force many of the decisions. It is more satisfying when matters are the results of the characters. Major accolades are given to Katey Sagal whose acting presents a range of emotions as her manipulative character takes pursues critically important avenues. The whole cast makes for an excellent ensemble. It should be difficult to care these violent criminals, yet this series makes the audience feel for them. There are new leading "good guys" are with another who is very eccentric yet the the fourth season presents them as more sympathetic and decent. This series continues on an overall excellent route.
summary: Great cast keeps an excellent series going forward

reviewText: Next to Breaking Bad and Oz, this is my favorite show. Interestingly this show is set in a Hamlet paradigm. It is both well acted and written. The three main characters Jax, Gemma, and Clay are multidimensional and engaging. It is a very interesting twist of a contemporary version of Hamlet. Katey Sagal is really the star. She gets to showcase her true acting talents in this series. Also of note she sings many of the songs on the show's outstanding soundtrack. Check out both the show and the different season soundtracks. Both will have you riveted!

reviewText: Kurt is a God. He was amazing on the Sheild, and now with Sons of Anarchy, well i dont think he can get anything better. My old man rides with a 1 percent club and so much of what the show is about is true life of a biker. The jail lock downs, and the club looking out for you till he is out again, the violence. It is not a way a life for the weak. I really hated the Clay and Gemma violence this 4th season only because they always played off each other so well and you really could beleive their love for each other. The only thing I would love for Kurt to change is to let Opie find some kind of happiness. Every season he gets crapped on from donna dieing then finding out that clay and tig betrayed him, to his new marraige is going down the toilet, and clay kills piney. Enough of Bobby getting locked down every season. That poor guy spends more time locked down then riding with the club. I honestly look fo clay to sorta move into the retired role that piney was in. i love piney though and not sure how next season will go without him. This is not a series you can really start watching from seaso 4 or the beginning of season5. You really have to follow the entire story from the season 1 on to really understand the whole situations going on. I also think we will see the end of Otto this next season. Poor Otto has pretty much gave everything he has and even his life because he is on death row now for getting back on the attack that left him blind, and the attack on jackson while he was in prison. This is an awsome show. and it only get better each season. I think Kurt picked the right people for each role. You will not be disappointed in this show

reviewText: I thought I loved the series at first, but I've reduced that opinion overall to "Like". The main reason is that in this fourth season I stopped believing it could really happen. Too many wierd things going on. I did really like the way Tara blossomed into a fit queen for Jax. He did everything he could to help her get out, planning to join her when he could, but then she chose to stay, showing a love and dedication I could only wish for in a woman. Overall the season was still very good, and I liked it very very much. I just can't say I loved it.

reviewText: I have to admit I have been hooked by SOA from the very first episode.  As the first several seasons developed, I began feeling like the show was turning into a soap opera dressed in leathers.  The plot lines revolved around who's screwing who, who's back-stabbing who, who's lying to who... but ultimately, that didn't matter, I eagerly awaited each show.I love the fact that the backstory is based on Hamlet.  That Jax is playing the part of Hamlet, Clay is Uncle Claudius, Jenna is Hamlet's mother Gertrude and JT is the ghost of Hamlet's murdered father.  You could even find parallels between Jax's best friend Opie and Hamlet's good friend Horatio.  About the only one that doesn't fit the scheme is Jax's girl Tara.  She's certainly no Ophelia, that is unless the writers intend on having her go mad and commit suicide.  Still, I like the way the writers have based the story on one of Shakespeare's greatest tragedies. It lends a story a level of class and sophistication that I wouldn't expect in a show about bikers.Another thing I like about the show is its sense of balance.  It's got everything; action, adventure, romance, intrigue, humor, it really has it all.  One week you're watching the Sons shoot it out with the Mayans, and the next week the show has me in practically in tears as Tig mistakenly kills Opie's wife Donna.Can't say enough about the acting.  There are no slouches in this cast.  Jax, Jenna and Clay are all superb.  I've even learned to appreciate the minor characters like the sheriff Wayne Unser.  He does an excellent job, as do the other supporting players like Bobby Elvis, Juice, Chibs and Opie.  Too, villans like Agent Stahl and U.S. Attorney Lincoln Potter are extremely well played and multi-dimensional.Like everyone else, I'm eagerly awaiting season 6.  Can't wait!

reviewText: The show itself is a 5, this episode is at best a 3. There's a problem with your finale if previous shows during the season surpassed it, easily. So many story lines that were built up all year, were tore down in seconds. Made it feel like a waste of time.Kurt Sutter said there may by a 6th or even 7th season. I can only imagine how they are going to drag this one out if that's the case. I like Sons of Anarchy, but how much longer can you drag this stuff out? Like anything, money comes before the story. They don't want to give away all of there story lines when they can still get 2+ more seasons of it.Season 3 was OK, and the finale saved it. Season 4 was GREAT and the finale diminished it in my eyes. I don't know which is worse. All I know is I'll be back in Charming next year, because it still is one of the best shows on television.

reviewText: Superb acting, great story lines, this show never lets up and after each episode you wonder how it can stay so strong and relevant after four years but it does!  The only "problem" is that you really need to watch this show from season 1 onward as there is so much character development throughout that picking it up in the middle would leave the viewer without a ton of necessary backstory.
